content: The "Corporate Responsibility Act of 2002" may require disgorgement. The Securities and Exchange Commission will prescribe regulations for disgorgement of various financial gains obtained by officers or directors of an issuer through misconduct in filing false or misleading financial statements. The Securities and Exchange Commission will have additional disgorgement authority in actions against individuals who engage in misconduct related to false or misleading financial statements. The Securities and Exchange Commission may require individuals engaged in misconduct related to false financial statements to disgorge benefits received, including salary, commissions, fees, bonuses, and profits from securities transactions. SEC. 3. CEO AND CFO ACCOUNTABILITY FOR DISCLOSURE. The Securities and Exchange Commission will require company executives to certify the accuracy of financial reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, ensuring they are free of misleading statements or material omissions. The signing officers are responsible for establishing and maintaining internal controls to ensure material information is known to them, and they have evaluated the effectiveness of these controls within 90 days prior to the report. The signing officers must disclose significant deficiencies in internal controls and any fraud involving management or employees to the issuer's auditors and audit committee. The rules required by subsection (a) shall be effective not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF UNFIT CORPORATE OFFICERS. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF UNFIT CORPORATE OFFICERS. Amendments are made to the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to replace "substantial unfitness" with "unfitness" in judicial proceedings. Additionally, in administrative proceedings, the Commission may issue an order to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 allows the Commission to prohibit individuals from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers if their conduct demonstrates unfitness. This authority can be exercised in cease-and-desist proceedings. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 empowers the Commission to bar individuals who violate regulations from acting as officers or directors of registered issuers if their conduct shows they are unfit for such roles.
